children.name: blackmail
children.definition: to force someone to give you money or do what you want, by threatening to tell people about something that they want to keep secret: tống tiền
examples: You cannot blackmail a man who has nothing to hide.
The priest was being blackmailed by a woman who said he was the father of her child.
blackmail[U noun] [C2] hăm dọa tống tiền
Bates got a 5-year jail sentence for blackmail.
‘If you don’t give me the money, I’m going to tell your wife.’ ‘This is blackmail!’
In a position of authority, a weakness for the opposite sex leaves youopento blackmail.
blackmailernoun[ C ] kẻ tống tiền

children.name: blackmail sb into (doing) sth
examples: She had tried to use the photographs to blackmail him into marrying her.
We will not be blackmailed into silence.

children.name: extort
children.definition: to illegally force sb to give you money by frightening or threatening them: tống tiền
examples: The terrorist groups have been extorting hundreds of millions of dollars.
He sought to extort money by threatening to reveal secrets about his boss’s private life.
extortion[U noun] the crime of extorting money: sự tống tiền
The defendant pleaded guilty to two counts of extortion.
Barratt is charged with extortion and murder.

children.name: extort money from/ out of sb :tống tiền ai
examples: The Mafia makes most of its money from prostitution and extorting money from small businesses.
For years the gang extorted money from local storekeepers.

children.name: to give or accept money illegally
graft
children.definition: dishonest behaviour by politicians who accept money from companies in return for helping them: nhận hối lộ
examples: Stevens was in court yesterday facing charges of graft and tax evasion.
A major investigation is underway to root out graft there, he said.

children.name: kickback
children.definition: a large amount of money that someone pays to a person in an important position in a company or government, in exchange for dishonestly arranging a business deal: tiền hối lộ, tiền lại quả, món tiền lót tay

children.name: $300/£400,000/millions etc in kickbacks
examples: Top executives received millions of dollars in kickbacks.

children.name: accept/take a kickback
examples: He is on trial for allegedly accepting kickbacks from business.
He and his partner were charged with taking $300,000 in kickbacks in exchange for their political influence.

children.name: pay/offer a kickback
examples: The company paid kickbacks to local officials to win contracts worth millions of dollars.
A cardiologist was offered kickbacks by a pacemaker manufacturer.

children.name: bribery
children.definition: when sb offers money to a politician or government official in order to persuade them to do something: sự hối lộ
examples: Officials said the bribery investigation would continue.
US firms are alleged to have used bribery to win contracts.
Several politicians are linked to the bribery and sex scandal.
bribery and corruption: tham nhũng hối lộ
The organization was rife with briberyand corruption.
bribe[T verb] [C1] to give money to sb in an official position, in order to persuade them to do sth that they should not do : hối lộ
Santo was convicted of bribing tax inspectors in Italy.
He bribed immigration officials and entered the country illegally.
bribe sb to do sth
He bribed a guard to smuggle a note out of the prison
bribe sb into doing sth
Judges are bribed or threatened into making decisions favorable to drug traffickers.
bribe[C noun][C1] money that sb gives to a person in an official position, in order to persuade them to do something that they should not do: tiền hối lộ, của hối lộ
The two brothers regularly used bribes and threats to further their business.
cash bribe[in the form of notes, rather than a cheque] hối lộ tiền mặt
He offered me a cash bribe to help him secure the contract.
$400/£30,000/millions etc in bribes
A customs official pocketed up to $500,000 in bribes for permitting cocaine to pass through the port.
offer (sb) a bribe
In all his years of public service, he has only been offered a bribe once.
Foreign firms willing to offer bribes typically win 80% of international deals.
pay a bribe (to sb)[give someone a bribe] hối lộ (ai đó)
Some companies in Belgium and France had paid bribes for the award of contracts.
They paid millions in bribes to tax officials in order to avoid investigation
take/accept a bribe
The judge admitted that he had accepted bribes.
During his term in office, he took bribes ranging from 22 million to 220 million yen.

children.name: backhander
children.definition: / bung   a small amount of money paid to someone to persuade them to do something that is dishonest but usually not very serious: của hối lộ, tiền đút lót
examples: He denies accepting backhanders, though he admits being offered them.
George gave the bouncer a bung, and we got into the nightclub.
There’s some suggestion that a backhander was involved.
Perhaps the landlord’s getting a backhander from the estate agent.

children.name: £300/£10 etc in backhanders
examples: Fifty pounds has already gone in backhanders to the guys in the security office.

children.name: perjury
children.definition: the crime of telling a lie in a court of law when you have promised to tell the truth:

children.name: commit perjury
examples: Do you realise that by lying to the court you have committed perjury?

children.name: charge sb with perjury
examples: Both witnesses are accused of giving false evidence and will likely be charged with perjury.

children.name: find sb guilty of perjury
examples: Hall was found guilty of perjury and obstruction of justice.

children.name: fraud
children.definition: the crime of getting money dishonestly from a big organization, for example by giving false information or changing documents, especially over a long time: tội gian lận, lừa đảo
examples: She was found guilty of fraud.
Big losses due to theft and fraud forced the company to close.
Landale is calling for more laws to protect consumers against fraud.
He is fighting extradition to Hong Kong to face trial on fraudcharges.
tax/insurance/credit card etc fraud
He’s been charged with tax fraud.
fraudulent[adj] [C2]intended to deceive people in an illegal way, in order to gain money, power etc : lừa đảo
A worrying trend for insurers has been a rise in fraudulentclaims.
afraudulentinsuranceclaim
afraudulent statement
fraudulent activity/behaviour/conduct etc.
fraudster[C noun] someone who gets money by deceiving people : người phạm tội lừa đảo
New measures are needed to prevent fraudsters opening bank accounts with stolen cheques.

children.name: corruption
children.definition: when sb who works for the government, the police etc uses their power dishonestly to get money or gain an advantage: sự tham nhũng
examples: The chief of police was forced to resign after allegations of corruption.
The administration has frequently been accused of corruption and abuse of power.
Political corruption is widespread throughout the country.

corrupt/kəˈrʌpt/ [adj] [C1] a corrupt politician, official, or police officer uses their power in a dishonest way for their own advantage, for example by accepting money from people in return for helping them: tham nhũng
In the 1970s, the city’s police force was among the most corrupt in the nation.
Corrupt customs officials have helped the drug trade to flourish.
Perez said that there were virtually no procedures in place to weed out corrupt officials

children.name: widespread corruption : tham nhũng lan rộng tràn lan
examples: Corruption has become so widespread there that you almost can’t imagine the system working without it.
The film is about a young police-officer and his struggle toexposecorruption in the force.

children.name: get at
children.definition: sbinformal to use threats to influence the decision of people who are involved in a court case:
examples: Do you think some of the jury have been got at?
The accused claimed that the witness had been got at.
The trial had to be abandoned when it was discovered that jury members had been got at by the Mafia.

children.name: nobble
children.definition: to make someone do what you want by illegally offering them money or threatening: “tóm cổ”
examples: The jury who convicted him were suspected of being nobbled.
The jury had been nobbled and the case had to be reheard.

children.name: get to
children.definition: sb informal to threaten witnesses, judges, or other people involved in a court case in order to influence the court’s decision: hăm dọa
examples: When the police questioned Davis, it was clear someone else had gotten to him first.
